<!-- please do not add an infobox, per [[Wikipedia:WikiProject Opera#Infoboxes]]--> '''Ana Raquel Satre''' was an [[opera]]tic [[soprano]], who was married to Patrick Bashford and was nicknamed 'Mimi'.<ref>[http://www.slv.vic.gov.au/hwtports/0/0/4/doc/hp004129.shtml State Library of Victoria]</ref>
==Biography== Satre was born in [[Uruguay]] and studied with French soprano [[Ninon Vallin]] at the Conservatorio Nacional in [[Montevideo]]. Her first success came at an early age when she was chosen to sing in [[Cimarosa]]'s ''[[Il matrimonio segreto]]'' at the Montevideo Opera House. She subsequently appeared in South America singing the title role in [[Peri]]'s ''[[Euridice]]'', Fiordiligi in ''[[CosÃ¬ fan tutte]]'' and Cleopatra in [[Handel]]'s ''[[Giulio Cesare]]''.
Satre's first European appearances were at [[Wigmore Hall]] in London, as part of Lies Askonasâ ''Voices of Tomorrow'' recital series, and as Euridice in [[GlÃ¼ck]]'s ''[[Orfeo]]'', opposite [[GÃ©rard Souzay]] in the title role, with the [[Aix-en-Provence Festival]]. She then went on Barcelona; [[La Fenice]]; Venice; [[La Monnaie]]; Brussels; and was invited by [[Gian Carlo Menotti]] to take part in the [[Spoleto Festival|Spoleto]] and Madrid Festivals. She toured Australia with the Elizabethan Theatre Trust appearing in Sydney, Melbourne, Brisbane and Perth and at the Adelaide Festival, as Donna Elvira in ''[[Don Giovanni]]'' and Violetta in ''[[La traviata]]'', for which she was awarded the 1963 Opera Medal of the Harriet Cohen International Music Awards.
In addition to her operatic work, Satre has toured extensively as a recitalist in Great Britain, most notably with [[Gerald Moore]] at the King's Lynn Festival in the presence of the Queen Mother, and in Austria, France, Italy, and North and South America. For [[Decca Records|Decca]], she has recorded Alisa in ''[[Lucia di Lammermoor]]'', Lola in ''[[Cavalleria rusticana]]'' and Emilia in ''[[Otello]]'' with [[Mario del Monaco]] and Renata Tabaldi.
In 1963, Satre interpreted Judith in a film version of [[BartÃ³k]]'s ''[[Bluebeard's Castle]]'' in German for Stuttgart Television and in English for world release with [[Michael Powell (director)|Michael Powell]].
Satre has sung under such conductors as [[Paul Paray]], Lamberto Baldi, Tulio Serafin, George PrÃªtre, [[Sir John Pritchard]], [[Sir Charles Mackerras]], Eric Simon and [[Herbert von Karajan]]. She currently teaches in Paris, France.
